race.name: Belgian Waffle Ride Cedar City
race.tagline: Half the climbing of San Diego. All the suffering. Plus miles of playground sand.

vitals.distance_options: Waffle ~127 mi, Wafer ~80 mi, Wanna ~40 mi
vitals.field_size: Hundreds of starters, deep North American pro field (Stetina, Gomez Villafañe, Roberge)
vitals.start_time: Near downtown Cedar City / Frontier Homestead
vitals.registration: Standard BWR online via belgianwaffleride.bike, Waffle $200-300 range
vitals.aid_stations: Several fully stocked. Riders report 3.5 hours at 23 mph between key stops.
vitals.cutoff_time: Multiple time checks. 2024 had route shortened due to weather.

climate.primary: High desert Utah - early spring weather roulette
climate.description: Early April at 5,600+ ft means below-freezing starts are common. 2024 had 'snowing sideways' pre-race day with freezing temps, high winds, and snow on run-in. Good years warm to 50s-60s°F.
challenges: Extreme variability: snow, freezing wind, rain possible
2024 edition: 'Don't expect a warm up as it won't get above freezing until mid-afternoon'
Cold hands and windchill at start
Dehydration risk once sun and pace pick up

terrain.surface: Fast-rolling but has 'hidden treachery.' Wide open valleys, ranch roads, farm doubletrack, and notorious 'playground type sand' sectors that wreck momentum. Steep washboarded descents after 110 miles.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: BWR brand cachet with unique playground sand sectors and weather roulette. Overall +3 for course character.

biased_opinion.summary: BWR Cedar City is what happens when you take the Waffle formula and add playground sand, mile-100 suffer-climbs, and Utah weather roulette. Half the climbing of San Diego but arguably more suffering because of where the difficulty is concentrated. The first 3.5 hours at 23 mph feel sustainable. The last 25 miles feel eternal.
biased_opinion.quote: '125 miles. 6k of climbing. 75% dirt. Starting at 5,600 ft. Technical riding and sand. Dry weather at elevation. Demoralizing.' - Rob Rides
strengths: The BWR brand: Professional organization with gravel pedigree
The surprise factor: 'Half the climbing' sounds easy until you hit the sand
The scenery: Expansive Utah valleys are stunning (when you can look up)
weaknesses: The weather: April in Utah can mean snow, freezing temps, or 60°F
The sand: Miles of playground sand destroy under-tired riders
The mile-100 combo: Sandy climb into rocky descent is brutal timing
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a BWR that tests a different set of skills - sand navigation, late-race focus, weather adaptability - Cedar City delivers. Just bring 40mm+ tires.

final_verdict.one_liner: Half the climbing of San Diego. All the suffering. Plus miles of playground sand and a soul-crushing mile-100 combo.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a different BWR challenge that tests sand navigation, weather adaptability, and late-race mental fortitude. Cedar City punishes under-prepared riders more than they expect. Come with 40mm+ tires, cold-weather layers, and a pacing plan that saves matches for mile 100.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want BWR with more climbing: San Diego original. If you want Utah gravel without sand: Crusher in the Tushar. If you want desert gravel with guaranteed weather: BWR Arizona.

logistics.airport: Cedar City Regional (CDC) - limited. Las Vegas (LAS) - 2.5 hours. Salt Lake City (SLC) - 4 hours.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Cedar City is a college town (SUU) and national parks gateway. Hotels exist but book up race weekend. Secure rooms well in advance.
logistics.food: College town with solid options. Not a foodie destination but functional.
logistics.packet_pickup: Standard BWR format: expo day before with 'waffle + beer' scene and tech partner booths.
logistics.parking: Start/finish near downtown. Large parking fields with no major complaints.

history.origin_story: Created to bring the BWR 'quadrupel' style of mixed-surface brutality to high-desert Utah. Half the climbing of San Diego but more sand and gravel to keep the 'unroad' identity intact. 2024 weather-shortened edition proved organizers will shorten the route if safety demands it.
notable_moments: 2020: Inaugural year - dry, dusty, demoralizing sand
2023: 'Most fun I've had in a gravel race in a long time' - Adam Roberge
2024: Snowing sideways pre-race, course shortened due to freezing temps and high winds
Part of the broader BWR series alongside California and Arizona editions
history.reputation: A real BWR, not watered-down. 'Slightly more approachable than San Diego' with less climbing but more sand and gravel. Same suffering, different landscape.

course_description.character: '125 miles. 6k of climbing. 75% dirt. Starting at 5,600 ft. Technical riding and sand. Dry weather at elevation. Demoralizing.' The first 3.5 hours average 23 mph. The last 25 miles average pain.

suffering_zones.label: The Fast Opening
suffering_zones.desc: First 3.5 hours at ~23 mph average. People burn matches trying to hold wheels in wind and on fast dirt, then pay later in the sand and climbs.

suffering_zones.label: Sand & Wind Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: Miles of 'playground type sand' and crosswinds cook legs. Under-tired wheels knife into sand causing crashes or walking. Source Endurance recommends at least 40mm tires.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Sand traps wreck momentum, under-tired = disaster

suffering_zones.label: The Soul Crusher
suffering_zones.desc: The mile-100 sandy climb is 'the most challenging climb of the course' - steep, sandy, when you're already cracked. Many report using every gear and still grinding. Cramps and walking common.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Steep sandy climb at altitude after 100 miles

suffering_zones.label: Rocky Washboard Descent
suffering_zones.desc: 20-minute rocky/technical section after the summit. 'A steep, washboarded descent jarring jaws and shoulders tenderized by 110 miles of mostly gravel.' Where tired riders crash or cramp.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Technical descent on exhausted legs, 5 miles from finish

course_description.signature_challenge: The mile-100 sandy climb leading straight into rocky/washboarded descending is the signature 'soul-crusher' that repeatedly appears in every race report.

prestige.explanation: First BWR outside California marks territory expansion, and when Pete Stetina shows up twice to win, you know the field respects this thing. The Quad-Tripel Crown series gives it legitimate standing in the gravel calendar. It's not Unbound, but drawing 600+ riders to Cedar City, Utah for punishment says something about brand power.

race_quality.explanation: Monuments of Cycling knows how to run events, and the 2026 course redesign removing sketchy singletrack for 'rippable unroad spiciness' shows they listen to feedback. Four feed zones for 117 miles is proper support. When weather forced a course shortening in 2024, they adapted instead of canceling—that's operational maturity.

experience.explanation: Red rock valleys, sandy sectors, and 360-degree desert views at 5,800 feet creates scenery most gravel races can't touch. The terrain 'never quite settles into comfort' which keeps you engaged for all 117 miles. Starting in 52°F and finishing in 85°F means you experience the full desert temperature swing in one day.

community.explanation: Forum discussions show equipment debates and course file sharing, but it's more transactional than tribal. The 'buy 3, get 4' Quad-Tripel Crown deal creates series followers, not necessarily Cedar City loyalists. It draws serious riders but hasn't built the cult following of some standalone events.

field_depth.explanation: Pete Stetina, Keegan Swenson, Sofia Gomez Villafane, and Rose Grant on the winner's list tells you the caliber. 600+ riders in the inaugural year shows it attracts numbers, not just names. Being part of the Quad-Tripel Crown means traveling pros treat it seriously, not as a training ride.

value.explanation: 117 miles of new terrain, four feed zones, and access to Utah's high desert for a weekend makes the entry fee work. The Quad-Tripel Crown deal adds value if you're doing multiple BWR events. Cedar City isn't Aspen-expensive, so lodging won't destroy your budget.

expenses.explanation: Cedar City keeps costs reasonable compared to resort destinations, and tiered early registration pricing helps if you plan ahead. The challenge is getting to southern Utah—it's not exactly a hub airport situation. Factor in potential gear needs for altitude and temperature swings, but overall expenses stay manageable.

length.explanation: 117 miles hits the sweet spot for gravel suffering—long enough to separate pretenders from contenders, short enough that mortals can finish before dark. The 66.5-mile Wafer option gives beginners an out without embarrassment. At 5,800 feet average elevation, those miles feel longer than sea level equivalents.

technicality.explanation: The 2026 course removes 'crazy singletrack' but keeps sandy sectors and rocky jeep roads that demand skill. 60% unroad means equipment choices matter—ENVE pros switched from aero wheels to G23s for good reason. Sandy washboard sections separate Bay Area riders from desert veterans.

elevation.explanation: 5,940 feet of climbing over 117 miles isn't Leadville brutal, but it's steady work. Starting at 5,846 feet means you're already thin on oxygen before you begin climbing. The elevation profile shows consistent rolling rather than massive single climbs—death by a thousand cuts.

climate.explanation: June in Cedar City delivers 12.73 hours of sunshine, 77-86°F highs, and only 2.73 precipitation days all month—basically perfect gravel weather. 26% humidity keeps you dry but demands serious hydration strategy. When the 2024 edition got snow and high winds, it was weather, not climate—June eliminates that variable.

altitude.explanation: 5,846 feet starting elevation makes this the highest BWR start, and you'll feel it in your lungs combined with 26% humidity. It's not Colorado brutal, but sea level riders need acclimatization time or suffer accordingly. The thin air amplifies every effort, especially when dust kicks up.

logistics.explanation: Cedar City isn't exactly a transportation hub—you're driving from Salt Lake or flying into smaller regional airports. The town handles 600+ riders fine, but accommodation options are limited compared to major cities. Course files going private in 2020 showed some early organizational hiccups that seem resolved.

adventure.explanation: Red rock valleys, sandy sectors, and rocky jeep roads at altitude in Utah's high desert—this is why gravel exists. The terrain 'never quite settles into comfort' across 117 miles of constantly changing surfaces. Starting cool and finishing hot under massive desert skies delivers the full Western experience most riders never see.
